dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A path of marigold petals leads up to an altar lovingly arranged in a humble cemetery. An old woman lights a cand as the smoke of burning copal wood dances lyrically upwar

dialogues.speaker: CARD
dialogues.text: The smoke lifts up toward lines of papel picado В­- cut p banners -- that sway gently in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think I'm cursed... 'cause of something that happened before I was even born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A story begins to play out on the papel picado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, a long time ago there was this family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The images on the papel picado come to life to illustrate father, a mother, and a little girl. The family is happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The papГЎ, he was a musician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The papГЎ plays guitar while the mother dances with her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and his family would sing, and dance, and count their blessings... (beat) But he also had a dream... to play for the world. (beat) And one day he left with his guitar... and never returned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man walks down a road, guitar slung on his back. In another vignette his daughter stands in the doorway, watc her papГЎ leave. Two feet step up next to her. It is her mamГЎ, hardened. She shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the mamГЎ...? She didn't have time to cry over that walkaway musician! (beat) After banishing all music from her life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman gets rid of all of her husband's instruments an records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She found a way to provide for her daughter... (beat) She rolled up her sleeves and she learned to make shoes. (beat) She could have made candy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amongst the papel picado, a stick swings at a strung up piГ±ata which bursts with candy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or fireworks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fireworks go off in the background...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or sparkly underwear for wrestlers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparkly underwear and a luchador mask hang on a line amon other linens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But no... she chose shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the papel picado, the little girl becomes a young woma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she taught her daughter to make shoes. And later, she taught her son-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She introduces a suitor to the family business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then her grandkids got roped in. As her family grew, so did the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the next vignette, a bunch of goofy grandchildren join the shoemaking. The shoe shop is full of family!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music had torn her family apart, but shoes held them all together. (beat) You see, that woman was my great- great grandmother, MamГЎ Imelda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TILT DOWN from the papel picado to the

dialogues.speaker: OFRENDA ROOM
dialogues.text: where a photo sits at the top of a beautiful altar. The photo features MAMГЃ IMELDA -- serious, formidable. She h a baby on her lap. Her husband stands beside her, but his face has been torn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died WAY before I was born. But my family still tells her story every year on DГ­a de los Muertos -- the Day of the Dead... (beat) And her little girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fade from the face of the little girl to present day MAMГ COCO (97), a living raisin, convalescing in a wicker wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my great grandmother, MamГЎ Coco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy (12) walks into frame and kisses her on the cheek. This is our narrator, MIGUEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HolГЎ, MamГЎ Coco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Julio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, my name is Miguel. MamГЎ Coco has trouble remembering things... But it's good to talk to her anyway. So I tell her pretty much everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS of Miguel with MamГЎ Coco:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to run like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel pumps his arms with his hands in fists. switches to flat palms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now I run like this which is way faster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel, in a luchador mask, climbs onto the bed, arms rai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the winner is... Luchadora Coco!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel leaps off the bed onto a pile of pillows that burs sending feathers onto MamГЎ Coco who wears a mask of her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel leans toward MamГЎ Coco at the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a dimple on this side, but not on this side. Dimple. No dimple. Dimple. No dimple--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel!   Eat your food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel's ABUELITA (70s) runs the table like a ship captai She gives MamГЎ Coco a kiss on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Abuelita? She's MamГЎ Coco's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita piles extra tamales on Miguel's plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you're a twig, mijo.         Have some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, gracias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked if you would like more tamales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S-sГ­?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I THOUGHT you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita runs our house just like MamГЎ Imelda did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita adjusts the photo of her beloved MamГЎ Imelda. T she perks her ear at a hooting sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel idly blows into a glass soda bottle.     Abuelita the bottle away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel listens as a truck drives by the window, blaring r tunes. Abuelita angrily slams the window shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No music!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trio of gentlemen serenade each other as they stroll by family compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) AUNQUE LA VIDA--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita bursts out of the gate and chases them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO MUSIC!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrified, the musicians stumble as they run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're the only family in MГ©xico who hates music...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Rivera family tinkering in the shoe shop, no m to be heard. Miguel jogs past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my family's fine with that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs his shine box, and heads out of the shoe shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be back by lunch, mijo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love you, MamГЎ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once outside, Miguel makes his way through the small town

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am NOT like the rest of my family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes a woman sweeping a stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hola, Miguel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hola!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes a band of musicians playing a tune. Miguel join with some air guitar and the further down the street he g the more instruments and sounds layer in. The bells of th church chime in harmony, a radio blares a cumbia rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running past a food stand, Miguel grabs a roll of pan dul and tosses the vendor a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muchas gracias!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De nada, Miguel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Miguel passes all these scenes, the music synthesizes he can't help but tap out rhythms along a table of alebri The fantastical wooden animal sculptures each play a different tone like a marimba. Miguel finishes with a SMA on a trash can, out of which a pops up a scrappy hairless Xolo dog. The dog, DANTE, barks and jumps up to lick Migu who laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey!    Dante!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel holds the pan dulce over Dante's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit. Down. Roll over.        Shake. Fist bump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dante obeys to the best of his ability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy, Dante!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel tosses the pan dulce to his furless friend who top back into the trash can.

dialogues.speaker: MARIACHI PLAZA
dialogues.text: Miguel rounds the corner toward the town square. Vendors sell sugar skulls and marigolds, and musicians fill the square with music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'm not supposed to love music -- but it's not my fault! (beat) It's his: Ernesto de la Cruz...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel approaches a statue of a handsome mariachi at the heart of the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The greatest musician of all time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tour group and their TOUR GUIDE are gathered around the base of the statue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And right here, in this very plaza, the young Ernesto de la Cruz took his first steps toward becoming the most beloved singer in Mexican history!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIPS of de la Cruz in his hay day: playing as a young ma the plaza, serenading bystanders in a train car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He started out a total nobody from Santa Cecilia, like me. But when he played music, he made people fall in love with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORE CLIPS from de la Cruz's films. He leaps from a tree branch onto a galloping horse. He plays his signature sku guitar with flourish and flair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starred in movies. He had the coolest guitar... He could fly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLIP features de la Cruz dressed as a hovering priest, up by strings, in front of a cycling sky flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he wrote the best songs! But my all-time favorite? It's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLIP of de la Cruz performing in a fancy nightclub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) REMEMBER ME THOUGH I HAVE TO SAY GOODBYE REMEMBER ME DON'T LET IT MAKE YOU CRY FOR EVEN IF I'M FAR AWAY I HOLD YOU IN MY HEART I SING A SECRET SONG TO YOU EACH NIGHT WE ARE APART REMEMBER ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOUGH I HAVE TO TRAVEL FAR REMEMBER ME EACH TIME YOU HEAR A SAD GUITAR KNOW THAT I'M WITH YOU THE ONLY WAY THAT I CAN BE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lived the kind of life you dream about... Until 1942...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the audience swoons over de la Cruz, an absent-minded stagehand leans on a lever. Ropes and pulleys go flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNTIL YOU'RE IN MY ARMS AGAIN REMEMBER ME!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De la Cruz is subsequently crushed by a giant bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he was crushed by a giant bell.

dialogues.speaker: MARIACHI PLAZA
dialogues.text: Miguel gazes up at the statue of de la Cruz in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna be just like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel weaves up to de la Cruz's mausoleum and peeks in t window. He catches a glimpse of de la Cruz's signature sk guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, I look at de la Cruz and I get this feeling... like we're connected somehow. Like, if HE could play music, maybe someday I could too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If it wasn't for my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playful) Ay, ay, ay, muchacho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked for a shoe shine, not your life story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel comes out of his reverie and looks up at the PLAZA MARIACHI whose shoes he is shining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to scrubbing the man's shoe.    As Miguel sh the mariachi plucks his guitar idly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't really talk about any of this at home so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if I were you I'd march right up to my family and say, "Hey! I'm a musician. Deal with it!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never say that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ARE a musician, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I mean... I only really play for myself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did de la Cruz become the world's best musician by hiding his sweet, sweet skills? No! He walked out onto that plaza and he played out loud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mariachi gets an idea. He points to the gazebo where organizers are setting up for a show. They unfurl a canva poster which reads "TALENT SHOW."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, mira, mira! They're setting up for tonight. The music competition for DГ­a de Muertos. You wanna be like your hero? You should sign up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh, my family would freak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you're too scared, then, well... have fun making shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.    What did de la Cruz always say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Seize your moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mariachi appraises Miguel, then offers his guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me what you got, muchacho. I'll be your first audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel's brows rise, surprised. He reaches to take the instrument, regarding it as if holding a holy relic. Miguel spreads his fingers across the strings anticipatin his chord and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIGUEL!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, Miguel impulsively throws the guitar back onto mariachi's lap. He turns to see Abuelita marching toward him. Miguel's TГЌO BERTO (40s) and PRIMA ROSA (16), follo with supplies from the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel quickly packs away his shine rag and polishes. Abuelita barrels up to the mariachi. She hits his hat with her shoe and waves him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave my grandson alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DoГ±a, please -- I was just getting a shine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know your tricks, mariachi! (to Miguel) What did he say to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just showing me his guitar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gasps from the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shame on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita lords over the mariachi, shoe aimed directly bet his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandson is a sweet little angelito querido cielito -- he wants no part of your music, mariachi! You keep away from him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mariachi scrambles away, snatching his hat off the ground before he goes. Abuelita hugs Miguel protectively her bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, pobrecito! EstГЎs bien, mijo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She peppers him with kisses then releases him from the embrace. He gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distressed) You know better than to be here in this place! You will come home. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita turns toward home. Miguel sighs and gathers his shine box. Then, seeing a flyer for the plaza "TALENT SHO he can't help but pocket it. He follows Abuelita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel catches up to his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times have we told you -- that plaza is crawling with mariachis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, TГ­o Berto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dante ambles up to Miguel, sniffing and whining for a tre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita shoos him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away, you! Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dante darts off, scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just Dante...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita throws her shoe at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never name a street dog.         They'll follow you forever. (beat) Now, go get my shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rivera workshop is abuzz with family making shoes. WHOMP! Miguel is plopped onto a stool, ready for a lectur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found your son in Mariachi Plaza!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Miguel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how Abuelita feels about the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just shining shoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A musician's shoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gasps from the family. PRIMO ABEL (19) is so shocked he loses his grip on the shoe he is polishing, which zips aw from the polisher and lodges itself in the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the plaza's where all the foot traffic is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Abuelita says no more plaza, then no more plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurting) But what about tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well they're having this talent show-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita perks her ear, suspicious.          Miguel squir whether to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thought I might...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MamГЎ looks at Miguel, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sign up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You have to have talent to be in a talent show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are YOU going to do, shine shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shoe from the ceiling falls back down on Abel's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's DГ­a de los Muertos -- no one's going anywhere. Tonight is about family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She deposits a pile of marigolds in Miguel's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ofrenda room. VГЎmonos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel follows his Abuelita to the family ofrenda, holdin the pile of flowers as she arranges them on the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that look. DГ­a de los Muertos is the one night of the year our ancestors can come visit us. (beat) We've put their photos on the ofrenda so their spirits can cross over. That is very important! If we don't put them up, they can't come! (beat) We made all this food -- set out the things they loved in life, mijo. All this work to bring the family together. I don't want you sneaking off to who-knows-where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up to find Miguel sneaking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were done...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, Dios mГ­o... Being part of this family means being HERE for this family... I don't want to see you end up like--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita looks up to the photo of the faceless musician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like MamГЎ Coco's papГЎ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mention that man!      He's better off forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're the one who--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta, ta, ta-tch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch-tch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch-tch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PapГЎ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look to find MamГЎ Coco agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PapГЎ is home...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MamГЎ, cГЎlmese, cГЎlmese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PapГЎ is coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No MamГЎ.   It's okay, I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MamГЎ Coco looks up at Abuelita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadness rises in Abuelita; she swallows it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest, MamГЎ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuelita returns to the ofrenda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hard on you because I care, Miguel. (beat) Miguel... Miguel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around the room. Miguel is nowhere to be found. Abuelita steps up to the ofrenda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sigh) What are we going to do with that boy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks to the photo of MamГЎ Imelda.       Abuelita's brighten with an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. That's just what he needs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TГ­o Berto unloads rolls of leather from a truckbed. Near Dante sleeps under the shade of a tree. He startles awake a faint TWANGING. The dog scrambles up to the roof. He reaches a shoe sign advertising the Rivera Family busi and lifts it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dante pokes his head in.      Miguel turns and gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you. Get in here, c'mon, Dante. Hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dante wriggles into the hideout. Miguel is huddled over something. The dog peeks around his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna get me in trouble, boy. Someone could hear me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel reveals a makeshift guitar, cobbled together from beat up old soundboard and random other items. He takes a china marker and sketches a nose on what appea to be his own version of a skull guitar head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish someone wanted to hear me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel tunes the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other than you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dante gives Miguel a big sloppy lick. Miguel gives a gros out chuckle. He lifts his guitar and strums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfecto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crawls to the far side of the attic where he's built h own ofrenda to Ernesto de la Cruz. Posters, candles, and songbooks are arranged with care. Miguel lights the candl with reverence, illuminating an album cover of de la Cruz holding his skull guitar. Miguel compares the head of his guitar to the album cover Then he imitates de la Cruz's pose and smile. He switches on a beat up old TV and pushes a tape into th VCR, "Best of de la Cruz" scrawled on the spine. A montage of the greatest moments from de la Cruz's films plays out. A clip from "A QUIEN YO AMO:"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to sing. I have to play. The music, it's -- it's not just in me. It is me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel strums his guitar as de la Cruz imparts his wisdom More clips run in the background as Miguel plays:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When life gets me down, I play my guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
